summary: This document contains two affidavits signed by Ghislaine Maxwell in December 2020, waiving her rights to contest extradition from the United Kingdom and France to the United States. The waivers are conditional on her being released on bail and are intended to be used by the U.S. government if she violates bail conditions and flees to those countries.

events.title: Maxwell Signs Extradition Waivers
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell signs affidavits waiving her rights to contest extradition from the United Kingdom and France to the United States, conditional on her release on bail.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center, Brooklyn, New York
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell holds citizenship in the United States, the United Kingdom, and France.
Maxwell has resided in the United States since approximately 1991.
The waivers are conditional and designed to be used by the U.S. government if Maxwell is released on bail and then violates her conditions by fleeing to the UK or France.
Maxwell confirms she has consulted with her counsel, Mark S. Cohen and Christian R. Everdell, and is making the waivers voluntarily.
The document reveals the U.S. government's proactive legal strategy to prevent Maxwell from using her foreign citizenship to avoid extradition if she flees.
